key_insight: Neural stochastic differential equations that learn state-dependent drift and diffusion can generatively model single-cell dynamics, producing more realistic trajectories and enabling in silico perturbation experiments.
problem_solved: Accurately capturing the inherently stochastic, state-dependent evolution of cellular states over time and enabling prediction of how perturbations alter developmental or disease trajectories.
method: Parameterize both drift and diffusion terms of a stochastic differential equation with neural networks (neural SDE) to model state-dependent dynamics.
Train the generative model on single-cell time-series or pseudo-time data to match observed distributions of trajectories.
Use the learned SDE for sampling, counterfactual/perturbation simulations, and comparison to baseline methods to demonstrate improved fidelity.
impact: Provides ML practitioners with a flexible, principled generative framework for modeling noisy temporal biological processes, improving predictive fidelity and enabling hypothesis-driven in silico perturbations that can guide experiments.
visual_elements: Schematic of a neural SDE: neural nets outputting drift and diffusion fields over cell-state space
Trajectory plot comparing real single-cell trajectories vs. model-generated trajectories and baselines
Vector field visualization showing learned state-dependent drift and diffusion magnitude across latent space
Before/after perturbation simulation: paired trajectories illustrating counterfactual effects of a perturbation
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
